ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more ASL to supplement what I have learned in ASL 110 and 120.

I cultivated a stronger understanding of conversational ASL, CLs, story-telling, and general vocabulary. I feel much more fluid in holding conversations and understanding. I learned how to take videos to see signing properly (from the weekly video modules).
loved this class. learned so much about the language and culture of the Deaf and was also able to engage with the Deaf community in a variety of meaningful ways
The key points of this course include additional vocabulary, grammar, and Deaf culture.
Grammar, effective conversational skills, storytelling, and lots about Deaf culture
Increased proficiency and conversational skills in ASL, and also learned about Deaf culture
Increased conversational proficiency, deepened vocabulary, and a broader understanding of Deaf culture
I have a working-knowledge of ASL! ASL 130 is where I felt I took the step from knowing some of the language to feeling confident in consistently engaging in conversation. I highly recommend it!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think that the course is really fun, and the only thing that I would change is to have the project ensure that students will get all of their service hours completed.

When reflecting on this course, I feel pulled toward the strengths. The professors across the board are all amazing and passionate in what they do. Service projects as a mandatory part of the class is critical into deeper understanding within the ASL at Yale community. It always feels clear how the homework helps with understanding sign language, and the feedback we are provided in helpful in growing as individuals. My only critique on weakness is when our homework or quizzes include signs that we aren't familiar with, it feels frustrating, but, this doesn't happen too often so it's a small critique.
all strengths - LOVE asl

The setup of this course was very conducive to student learning. The homework, quizzes, and projects all strengthened different aspects of ASL, and the 4/1 schedule (M-Th synchronous, F asynchronous) worked very well, especially when it came to planning service projects or other events.

Professor Fisher is amazing. He comes to every class excited to teach.  He gives feedback on all of our signing which helps a lot. The curriculum is well structured for learning. My only suggestion would be to have short exams on hard skills (finger spelling, sentence structure to avoid signed English).

The strength is definitely the professor. Andrew is amazing and wants students to do well in the class. He is very understanding if you ask for help, and the class itself is structured for a lot of engagement

The service projects really vary in terms of students' engagement and commitment. I personally had a great time with my project, but the variability of experiences was apparent throughout the class. The amount of conversation practice was really helpful this semester and I enjoyed getting to know my classmates through the discussion prompts over time.

Strengths: Andrew *freaking* Fisher. He is a brilliant teacher and one of the kindest people you'll ever meet.

Weaknesses: None (other than the fact that teaching has kept Professor Fisher from pursuing an acting career....you'll see :).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I would recommend it to anybody interested in learning ASL and/or about Deaf and hard of hearing culture.

Yes! Sign language is the best language department here at Yale. If you are contemplating whether or not you should take sign language, talk to any student in the department; I guarantee they will rave about the community and friends they have found in class. You also learn the criticalness of better accessibility for everyone in the wider world. It's so much more than a language. It's genuinely learning about the culture.

Absolutely. This course - as was the entire ASL sequence - was incredible. All of the professors are invested in your learning and are wonderful both as teachers and individuals. You will learn so much and become a member of a wonderful signing community.
YES! I took this course for a language requirement--but am so grateful I did. Well designed, well taught, well supported.
Definitely! Great course and great professor!
Yes! Continue taking ASL! Even if you have your language requirement! WOOO go ASL!
Absolutely, especially with Professor Fisher. He is a saint.
I cannot recommend the ASL curriculum enough. It is not only the best class offered at Yale but the professors are phenomenal, kind, and just great people who care so much about their students.
